dataset.title: Transportation GIS Layers for the Eastern Shore of Virginia 2013

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Environmental Sciences, Clark Hall, University of Virginia

metadataProvider.organizationName: Virginia Coast Reserve Long-Term Ecological Research Project

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Virginia, 291 McCormick Road, PO Box 400123

abstract.para: This datasets contain GIS shapefiles related to the transportation infrastructure of Accomack and Northampton Counties on the Eastern Shore of Virginia. Included here are roads and highways, railroads, airfields and airstrips, boat ramps, and electrical transmission lines. Data was compiled from multiple sources. The primary purpose of this dataset is to provide VCRLTER researchers and students with a convenient up-to-date set of GIS data layers in one location that can be used as base layers for various map products and for planning research activities. A secondary purpose of this dataset is to extend transportation data coverage in the VCRLTER data catalog to include Accomack County and to supersede older USGS DLG data contained in the Northampton County GIS data package (VCRLTER dataset VCR14219).

The UVA grants you (hereafter, Licensee) a license to use the data and documentation for academic, and research purposes only, without a fee.
Licensee may make derivative works. However, if Licensee distributes any derivative work based on or derived from the data and documentation, then Licensee will

listitem.para: notify the VCR/LTER designated contact (typically the investigator who collected the data) regarding its distribution of the derivative work, and
clearly notify users that such derivative work is a modified version and not the original data and documentation distributed by the UVA.
acknowledge the support of NSF Grants BSR-8702333-06, DEB-9211772, DEB-9411974, DEB-0080381, DEB-0621014 and DEB-1237733 in any publications using the data and documentation.
send to the address, above, two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the data and documentation.

section.para: Any Licensee wishing to make commercial use of the data and documentation should contact the UVA, c/o VCR/LTER, to negotiate an appropriate license for such commercial use. Commercial use includes

listitem.para: integration of all or part of the data and documentation into a product for sale or license by or on behalf of Licensee to third parties, or
distribution of the data or documentation to third parties that need it to utilize a commercial product sold or licensed by or on behalf of Licensee.

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Virginia, 291 McCormick Road, PO Box 400123

description.para: As of February 2014, the most recent and best available large-scale (high resolution) road data from USGS via the National Map was generated from 2012 TIGER/Line data from the U.S. Census Bureau. For this reason, the 2013 TIGER/Line shapefiles (August 22, 2013 release) were downloaded directly from the USCB (http://www.census.gov/geo/maps-data/data/tiger-line.html#tab_2013). County-level road data, state-level landmark data (from which airfield point data were then extracted), and national-level rail data were downloaded. County-level road data were combined for Accomack and Northampton Counties, and those rail lines and airfields within the same two counties were extracted from the larger state- and national-level datasets.

Two attributes were added to the road data. One (FIPS) was the county FIPS code (51001 for Accomack, 51131 for Northampton). The second attribute (FEATURE) was added to provide a brief description of the Census Bureau's MAF/TIGER Feature Class Code (MTFCC) based on Appendix G of the 2013 TIGER/Line technical documentation (http://www.census.gov/geo/maps-data/data/pdfs/tiger/tgrshp2013/TGRSHP2013_TechDoc_G.pdf). There are no primary roads (i.e., Interstate highways) in this region. U.S. and state highways (e.g., U.S. Route 13) and major roads are included in the secondary road (MTFCC S1200) classification. Of note, the "local road" class (MTFCC S1400) includes both public and private roads by definition, and from observation includes many longer unpaved gravel and shell driveways and farm roads in this largely-rural region. Other types of farm roads and service roads are included with their own designations. Unpaved roads less than 50m long are generally not included; this includes most residential driveways.
Airfield point data was not modified in any additional way after extraction. All airports, airfields, and land strips are coded as MTFCC K2451.

The extracted national-level rail data appeared to have originated from 1:100,000 or smaller (coarser) scale data and exhibited numerous spatial inaccuracies. Therefore, the rail lines of the Eastern Shore (all listed as MTFCC R1011 and belonging to the Eastern Shore RR in the TIGER/Line data) were manually digitized based on VGIN-VBMP 2013 aerial imagery (1 ft. resolution, digitized at approximately 1:2000 scale or better). Sidings and spur lines that appear to still have rails and connect to the main trunk line were included, but these lines may not, in fact, still be actively used or have functioning rails. One purpose for including better located rail lines (and, by extension, the raised railroad beds) is to facilitate accurate modelling of surface hydrology by VCRLTER researchers.

Historically, large electrical transmission lines (not distribution lines) where included along with airport boundaries in the "Miscellaneous Transportation Features (MTF)" of USGS Digital Line Graph (DLG) data. While it appears that USGS no longer maintains this type of data for easy public download (the most recent archived DLG data in SDTS format for the two counties is circa 1968-1989, depending on the date of the most recent 7.5-minute quadrangle map revision), we have included transmission line data with other transportation-related base map data because it is useful for locating areas within the power line right-of-ways that are maintained in a perpetual non-forested state when conducting analyses involving landuse/landcover data. As a result, we digitized transmission lines based on VGIN-VBMP 2013 aerial imagery (1 ft. resolution, digitized at approximately 1:2000 scale or better) with the purpose to update and extend the transmission line data previously compiled from 1:100,000 scale USGS DLG data for Northampton County to now include data for Accomack County as well.

Finally, most of the public and/or state-owned boat ramps of the Eastern Shore of Virginia were included in this dataset because boat travel is an important mode of transportation in this coastal area. Potential boat access and distance from launch points is an important consideration when planning VCRLTER research activities in tidal wetland, submerged seagrass, barrier island, and other estuarine and lagoonal habitats. Multiple online data sources (listed below) were used in 2009 to identify and locate boat ramps in the area. Coordinates (if given) in source material were used to get approximate locations. Locations were then verified or relocated if necessary based on aerial imagery from VGIN-VBMP and Google Earth. Attribute information pertaining to ownership, structural type, and usage restrictions was inferred from source material and no attempt has been taken to confirm that the information collected is correct.
Source materials for boat ramp locations include:

listitem.para: VA Department of Game and Inland Fisheries (DGIF) - Public Boat Access website (http://www.dgif.virginia.gov/boating/access/)
Virginia Marine Resources Commission (VMRC) - List of Saltwater Access Projects
Coastal Travel Guide (coastaltravelguide.com) - "Coastal Virginia Public Boat Ramps and Fishing Piers" webpage (http://www.coastaltravelguide.com/Virginia/Virginia/VirginiaPublicBoatRamps.htm)
USFWS's Eastern Shore of Virginia National Wildlife Refuge - Information page for the Wise Point Boat Ramp (http://www.fws.gov/refuge/Eastern_Shore_of_Virginia/visit/boatlaunch.html)

VA Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) - Virginia Seaside Water Trail Map with Launch Sites (http://www.deq.state.va.us/Programs/CoastalZoneManagement/CZMIssuesInitiatives/SeasideWaterTrail/TrailMapwithLaunchSites.aspx)
Various planning documents from Accomack and Northampton Counties

spatialVector.entityDescription: Roads and highways of the Eastern Shore of Virginia (Accomack and Northampton Counties) 2013. Format: zip file containing ArcINFO shapefile. Source: U.S. Census Bureau TIGER/Line shapefiles (August 22, 2013 release). County-level data combined and descriptive attribute data added by VCRLTER.

textDomain.definition: The second attribute (FEATURE) was added to provide a brief description of the Census Bureau’s MAF/TIGER Feature Class Code (MTFCC) based on Appendix G of the 2013 TIGER/Line technical documentation (http://www.census.gov/geo/maps-data/data/pdfs/tiger/tgrshp2013/TGRSHP2013_TechDoc_G.pdf). There are no primary roads (i.e., Interstate highways) in this region. U.S. and state highways (e.g., U.S. Route 13) and major roads are included in the secondary road (MTFCC S1200) classification. Of note, the “local road” class (MTFCC S1400) includes both public and private roads by definition, and from observation includes many longer unpaved gravel and shell driveways and farm roads in this largely-rural region. Other types of farm roads and service roads are included with their own designations. Unpaved roads less than 50m long are generally not included; this includes most residential driveways.

horizontalAccuracy.accuracyReport: The Census Bureau uses Global Positioning System (GPS) coordinates at road centerline intersections to evaluate the horizontal spatial accuracy of source files that may be used to realign road features in the MAF/TIGER database and test the horizontal spatial accuracy of the road features in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles. The test compares a survey-grade GPS coordinate to its associated road centerline intersection in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles. The test is based on an independent collection of GPS coordinates for a random sample of road intersections from a centerline file that meet certain criteria. The points are referred to as the sample points and are gathered through a private contractor working for the Census Bureau. Since the collection method uses survey-quality GPS-based field techniques, the resulting control points are considered 'ground truth' against which the TIGER road centerline intersection coordinates are compared. The distances between the coordinates are calculated and the Census Bureau determines the Circular Error 95% (CE95). That is, the accuracy of the file in meters with 95% confidence. The CE95 can be calculated from the mean and standard deviation by using the formula: mean of differences plus (2.65 times the standard deviation). CE95 results reported for each file tested are determined using a spreadsheet with embedded statistical formula. The use and applicability of the spreadsheet and its embedded formula have been verified by Census Bureau statisticians. The basis of the calculation is the use of the root mean square error (RMSE). This is the method as stated in the U.S. Government's Federal Geographic Data Committee Standard FGDC-STD-007.3-1998, Geospatial Positioning Accuracy Standards. Part 3: National Standard for Spatial Data Accuracy. The results of using this measure of accuracy are in compliance with Federal Spatial Data requirements. In terms of the Census Bureau application, the dataset coordinate values are those taken from the centerline file and the coordinate values from an independent source of higher accuracy are those acquired through the Census Bureau's contractor. Please note that the horizontal spatial accuracy, where reported, refers only to the realigned road features identified as matched to the positionally accurate source file with that accuracy. It is not the spatial accuracy of the TIGER/Line Shapefile as a whole.

quantitativeAccuracyReport.quantitativeAccuracyMethod: The Census Bureau uses root mean square error (RMSE) as stated in the FGDC-STD-007. 3-1998, Geospatial Positioning Accuracy Standards, Part 3: National Standard for Spatial Data Accuracy.

spatialVector.entityDescription: Airports, airfields, and airstrips of the Eastern Shore of Virginia (Accomack and Northampton Counties) 2013. Format: zip file containing ArcINFO shapefile. Source: U.S. Census Bureau TIGER/Line shapefile (August 22, 2013 release). State-level data clipped to just the Eastern Shore of VA and only the airfield landmarks (points coded as MTFCC K2451) retained by VCRLTER.

codeDefinition.definition: regular boat ramp, generally wide enough for most VCRLTER boats and trailers.
